I will have to disagree with Moutaz, using HTTPs enables much more
flexibility for several reasons, HTTP/s optimized for slow network and reconnect, you can also do encryption, WAN optimization and you will have
more control over it.

don't use direct IP, you will regret it.

Use online database and you store your data offline in JSON and Sync the data once you find internet connection. if you are offline you can ping your server every 2-3 minutes. once you get a response stop pinging your server and just work online.
XML is old fashion thought! use JSON.

I would recommend working offline by default and not to ping the server every minutes... in a real production environment with multiple clients access this technique could make a lot of problems i.e loads of traffic to the server...
If the application is working offline by default you could do the sync process 2 or 3 times daily for every client in different times.
I think because financial data is all about stock level and money, you cannot work offline unless you don't have an internet connection available at this time.

so the default MUST be an online solution that connects to a WCF/Web service which the client initiate the first call with the service to acquire an access token, and using this access token with all future communications until it get expired.

this approach will insure that the data is always in sync, so querying stock level should always be reflected by the most recent changes, and a secure HTTPs communication mean is being used to avoid sniffing the request data.
conclusion: a mix of Moutaz Shams's solution and my suggestion is what I can think about right now.
Keep it simple. Don't do anything unless you *have to*. If the branches have good connections, then ignore offline storage.
